title: Veroz: Freelance Courier Delivery Pooling System
summary: Full-stack delivery management platform enabling freelance couriers to pool deliveries and optimize routes via real-time WebSocket tracking and dynamic pricing.

problem.description: Freelance couriers operate inefficiently with individual requests, leading to high operational costs and lack of real-time visibility for clients and admins.

system_overview.input: User Geolocation + Order Specs + Courier Status
system_overview.output: Real-time tracking updates + Optimized assignments + Financial payouts

your_contributions: Designed and implemented a modular REST API using Express and Prisma with role-based access control and service-layer separation.
Engineered transactional order state transitions using PostgreSQL row-level locking to prevent concurrent courier assignment conflicts.
Implemented dual-layer authentication: JWT with refresh rotation for user sessions and HMAC-SHA256 signatures for request integrity in public APIs.
Developed real-time delivery tracking using SSE for low-latency server-to-client event streaming.

results.evaluation: Complete end-to-end system with production-ready real-time tracking, dual-layer security, and comprehensive documentation.

engineering_decisions.reason: Ensures stateless scalability while maintaining high security for long-lived courier sessions.
Provides request integrity and non-repudiation for 3rd party integrations without OAuth2 overhead.
Critical for low-latency GPS updates and instant delivery notifications.

limitations: Location accuracy is currently tethered to client-side GPS signal quality
Pricing model lacks real-time traffic data integration
Vertical scaling limit based on single-node SSE connections management
future_work: ML-based route optimization using TSP algorithms
Native mobile applications for background location tracking
Predictive analytics for delivery demand forecasting
Introduce Redis Pub/Sub for distributed event broadcasting across multiple API instances

title: Defining the Landscape of Pathogenic Features
summary: A deep learning framework to predict bacterial pathogenicity and virulence factors directly from protein sequences using molecular evolution signatures.

problem.description: Predicting the pathogenicity of emerging or uncharacterized bacterial proteins where traditional homology-based methods (BLAST) fail due to low sequence similarity.
constraints: Memory-intensive feature space (8,900+ dimensions) on 12GB VRAM
Risk of data leakage via taxonomic memorization

components: 1D Convolutional Neural Network (Conv1D) for motif detection
Self-Attention mechanism for long-range residue dependencies

your_contributions: Developed a memory-efficient k-mer encoding pipeline managing 8,928-dimensional sparse genomic features.
Implemented a hybrid Conv1D + Attention model in PyTorch for hierarchical biological feature extraction.
Conducted model auditing using SHAP to verify focus on functional motifs over taxonomic labels.
Engineered a multi-label classification system for 14 distinct Virulence Factor categories.
Resolved XAI pipeline bottlenecks for sparse high-dimensional sequence data.

results.evaluation: Validated via SHAP GradientExplainer; model successfully learned universal pathogenic motifs rather than taxonomic identifiers.

engineering_decisions.reason: Provides fixed-width input for variable-length sequences, optimizing high-dimensional memory efficiency.
Prevents data leakage/memorization, forcing the model to learn raw biological signatures.
Dramatic reduction in memory footprint compared to Permutation-based explainers for 8k+ dimensions.

limitations: Retraining required for significant shifts in microbial pangenomes
Potential for false negatives in extremely rare or novel virulence mechanisms
future_work: Integrating ESM-2 (Evolutionary Scale Modeling) embeddings
Cross-genus zero-shot generalization testing
Expanding to environmental metagenomic risk assessment

short_card.title: Pathogenic Feature Discovery
short_card.tagline: Sequence-based DL for virulence factor classification

title: Multivariate Air Quality Forecasting with NeuralForecast
summary: Thesis project on multivariate time-series forecasting of air pollutants (PM10, NO2, SO2, O3) using NeuralForecast deep learning models with rich meteorological and temporal features.

problem.description: Forecasting multiple air pollutants several days ahead using heterogeneous meteorological and temporal signals under non-stationary and noisy conditions.
constraints: Limited robustness of classical statistical models

system_overview.input: Historical pollutant concentrations + weather variables + temporal encodings

components: Feature engineering (lags, rolling windows, calendar features)

your_contributions: Formulated the forecasting problem and experimental setup for multi-horizon prediction.
Designed a multivariate feature engineering strategy utilizing 54 distinct features.
Implemented NeuralForecast models and handled non-stationarity via temporal splits.
Evaluated deep learning models against classical and recurrent (LSTM) baselines.
Documented methodology and outcomes as a formal bachelor thesis.

results.evaluation: Rolling-origin evaluation comparing NeuralForecast models against ARIMA and LSTM baselines on held-out temporal splits.

engineering_decisions.reason: Provided research-backed, optimized implementations for multi-horizon deep time-series forecasting.
Captures cross-pollutant dependencies and shared temporal dynamics compared to independent univariate models.

limitations: Performance degradation during extreme weather patterns
Retraining required for long-term distribution shifts
future_work: Probabilistic forecasting using quantile or distributional outputs
Concept drift detection and adaptive retraining
Extension to spatial or graph-based air quality modeling

short_card.title: Air Quality Forecasting
short_card.tagline: 7-day multivariate air pollutant forecasting with deep time-series models

title: Vehicle Detection & License Plate Recognition Pipeline
summary: An end-to-end computer vision system for vehicle detection and automatic license plate recognition using a multi-stage YOLO, RCNN, and OCR pipeline.

problem.description: Automatically detecting vehicles and extracting license plate text from high-noise environments where lighting, varying angles, and occlusion typically break standard OCR.
constraints: Variable lighting and adverse weather conditions
Requirement for high-precision bounding box localization

system_overview.output: Localized Bounding Boxes + Extracted Plate Alphanumerics

your_contributions: Architected the full end-to-end vision pipeline from preprocessing to text extraction.
Implemented and tuned YOLO and RCNN models to balance real-time speed with detection robustness.
Integrated a hybrid OCR ensemble to improve extraction accuracy across low-quality plate images.
Developed a modular evaluation framework using mAP, IoU, and F1-score metrics.
Organized the project structure for seamless transition between research and production environments.

results.evaluation: Validated on held-out test sets using standard object detection benchmarks and per-character OCR accuracy metrics.

engineering_decisions.reason: Allows for flexible switching between high-speed real-time processing and maximum detection precision.
Reduces failure rates by leveraging multiple extraction algorithms (EasyOCR and PaddleOCR) to handle varying fonts and noise.

limitations: Performance degradation on extremely low-resolution or heavily occluded plates
High sensitivity to extreme plate angles and severe motion blur
Inference currently optimized for single images rather than high-FPS video
future_work: Transition to real-time video stream processing
Implementation of multi-frame vehicle tracking
Deployment of a REST API for remote inference
Edge-device optimization for low-power hardware

short_card.tagline: End-to-end CV pipeline for detection and alphanumeric extraction
